children.text: George Osborne will today use a £10 billion windfall from a booming economy to offer voters a taste of post-austerity Britain as he kicks off the Conservatives’ election campaign.

The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) will upgrade GDP growth for this year and next in today’s budget, giving the chancellor room to ease planned spending cuts while meeting the deadline to clear the deficit and fund tax cuts for millions of workers.

Hollywood is full of sycophants but some don’t play the game. In Total Film magazine Sir Kenneth Branagh reveals a letter from Woody Allen, asking him to play Lee Simon in his 1998 film Celebrity. “When I wrote this part, I knew there was only one actor in the world who could play it: Alec Baldwin,” Allen wrote. “But he’s unavailable. So I considered for a while Mel Gibson, but decided in the end that you would be more appropriate. Lee Simon is a loser, but attractive to women.” Sounds like every character played by Allen himself.

As we head into budget week, thanks to Adrian Brodkin who has observed that an anagram of “Chancellor George Osborne” is “Con, rob, recharge, sell on, ego.” Seems to sum up most chancellors. Ian Hale, meanwhile, worries for our children should Tristram Hunt become education secretary. An anagram of his name is “truants’ mirth”

Stanley Johnson told an Oldie lunch last week that he made his second daughter, Julia, cry when he announced on Have I Got News for You that he was the proud father of “Boris, Rachel, Leo, Jo and Max”. The potent but forgetful paterfamilias had this advice: “Write the names of your children on your knuckles. If you’ve got more than five children, write them on both hands.” It’s a relief for humanity that he stopped at just six

As one of our top forensic anthropologists, who has led teams identifying bodies in Kosovo, Iraq and after the Indian Ocean tsunami of 2004, Professor Sue Black needs a strong stomach. In a talk last week, she revealed her training: at the age of 12 she had a job in the freezer of a butcher’s shop in Inverness. “It was a mind-numbingly cold place to work,” she said. “We used to love it when the lorry brought livers from the abattoir as they had to be fresh. You could stick your hands into the buckets of livers and it would warm you up.” What an offal experience.
